Name: @DJPapzin
Comment:
üéØ Key Takeaways for quick navigation:

00:00 *üåø Introduction to Cannabis and Sleep*
- Introduction to cannabis use and its prevalence,
- Personal interest in cannabis and sleep,
- Questions about the impact of cannabis on sleep.
00:42 *üåô Positive Effects of THC on Sleep*
- THC helps decrease sleep onset latency,
- Benefits for people with insomnia, depression, and PTSD,
- Improved sleep duration and quality with occasional use.
02:07 *üß† Benefits of CBD on Sleep*
- CBD may aid in body temperature regulation and adenosine interaction,
- Potential reduction in anxiety and promotion of restful sleep,
- Research is still early, with dose-dependent effects.
03:00 *üö´ Negative Effects of THC on Sleep*
- THC's impact on REM sleep, reducing its duration and intensity,
- Consequences like impaired cognitive abilities and increased grogginess,
- REM rebound effects and withdrawal symptoms.
05:07 *üò¥ Cannabis Use and Sleep Disturbances*
- Chronic users experience more sleep disturbances,
- Higher likelihood of insomnia and irregular sleep durations,
- Correlation vs. causation in sleep issues related to cannabis use.
06:31 *üè• Health Implications of Poor Sleep*
- Optimal sleep duration and risks of deviating from it,
- Long-term health risks associated with insufficient or excessive sleep,
- The need for more research to determine causality.
07:14 *‚úã Personal Reflection and Conclusion*
- Personal experience of improved rest after reducing cannabis use,
- Importance of moderation and taking breaks,
- Encouragement for audience interaction and further resources.

Made with HARPA AI

Name: @d.w.stratton4078
Comment: 5:40 My question of this study is: what % of the insomniac students were using marijuana BECAUSE they had insomnia and were trying to treat it? That's a major potentially confounding factor, because it would be wrong to conclude that they were having insomnia BECAUSE they used marijuana when in fact the converse was true: they were using marijuana BECAUSE they had insomnia. That's a pretty common reason for weed use in moderation and would heavily skew the study if misinterpreted.

Name: @drew-shourd
Comment:
Decent video, much was left incomplete imo. Btw, I smoke every day, all day, have for 44 years (how old are you?...hehehe) I live down here in Michigan, where we can have 12 plants, so I am very well versed on growing and harvesting cannabis. Plus I am well experienced on seed varieties, levels of THC, percentage of either sativa or indica, or even rudaralis if they are auto-flowers. When I lived in Los Angeles (1985-2013)  I started an edible company, Wake and Bake Foods and was mostly making teas and chewy (and healthy) granola bars. I am also very aware that the same type and level of THC (and CBD) can affect the same person differently, on a daily basis, for one reason, what kind and how much food is in their stomach....and that's just one variable out of dozens. So all these medical studies hold some credence for me, although most are done by people who don't partake or really understand it, except possibly molecularly and biochemically. 
And personally, I have and remember amazingly detailed dreams ON cannabis, so much for that study aye?
Funny how you compare dispensaries with fast food places, when one is natural medicine while other is straight up poison. I feel as if you need to do a follow up video titled, "How Fast Food Completely Changes Your Sleep'....cause we all know it does, trans fats, high salt, high sugar and even higher preservatives.

Name: @jaec45
Comment:
I'm a sixty-eight year old retired senior who has R.A. (Rheumatoid Arthritis) on both ankles, both knees, and both shoulders, and also Gout.  I've had these chronic problems for a long time now I couldn't walk for a block or cross the street easily by myself.  I have taken several pain medications but the pain lingers.
In 2020, when Cannabis was legalized in Chicago, my son suggested I try it.  I was hesitant of course because of the bad publicity of Marijuana.  I tried smoking it at first, but it made me dizzy and nauseous.  So then I started taking it as "tea".  My son makes a concoction of Canna-butter and I would take about 10 ml. of the cannabutter, dissolve it in a hot cup of tea, then drink it before bedtime.
Since then, my mobility has improved dramatically and I could sleep peacefully and longer too.  I've been using "Cannabis Indica" (not Sativa) since 2020 up to the present and I don't feel any untoward effects.  I can walk five blocks now, take public transport, sleep soundly at night, no hallucinations or depression (I also take Vit.D3 2000 units to prevent depression since I don't get as much sunlight anymore).  I feel great is all I can say.
The only thing I notice that is unusual, for me, is an increase in my appetite.  Other than that, I feel like I'm in my forties again.
.

In other respects however it allowed me to be more ready in the morning since it prolonged my very short sleep cycle, which is short even by short sleeper standards.
We talk 3-5 hours when sober with three making me just slightly tired, which usually got fixed with a "Garfield style" coffee in the morning and 5 making me extremely tired to the point of sometimes calling in sick for the day (as strange as it may sound sleeping over 6 hours when clean and off never helped and in general I always felt like a zombie in the morning). Weed improved this insomnia-like state by adding hour or two while eliminating the tiredness almost completely. It also greatly helped with other issues such as my tendency towards anger outbursts (even when not high), voracious hunger, restlessness, depressions, ...and so on.

And for those who think that talking to proffessional could help...it never did. On the contrary it always just made things worse.

Name: @ElSantoLuchador
Comment: Delayed and suppressed REM isn't necessarily a bad thing, in fact it's the goal in some of the therapies for REM related disorders like narcolepsy and sleep paralysis.  In all cases part of the problem is sleep stage intrusion, in this case REM cycles intruding on the wake state. Often the drug of choice for such projects are good old anti-depressants.  If you take SSRI's I can absolutely assure you that your REM is delayed and reduced.  I've seen it thousands of times.   "Taking the rapid out of REM" is known as SREM in the business (slow REM), but most people refer to it as 'Prozac eyes'.  REM abundance after the cessation of the REM suppressant is known as "REM Rebound" and can be quite pronounced.   (I worked in sleep medicine for 20 yrs, but I'm not claiming expert status).

Name: @carlgranados7106
Comment: I'm 69I was smoking pot every night for the last 15 years or so but recently quit.  I quit because I was starting to have equilibrium issues with my vision spinning the room around when I went to bed and affecting during the day.  There is a condition called Cannabinoid Hyperemesis Syndrome (CHS) which some pot smokers get who have been smoking for a long time.  As a 68 year old this was unacceptable for obvious reasons.  I should also mention that pot was not as enjoyable as it used to be.  I believe that the reason for this is that the "manufactured" pot you get today is not as good as "good" pot used to be when I was a teenager although the THC is higher.  Of course this is only a theory.  The point being is that it wasn't hard for me to quit.  My bad symptoms quickly went away and I do feel somewhat more focused also.  The main difference is that I am dreaming again which I only realized had almost completely gone away.  I will still smoke a bit a couple of times a month but nothing like before.

Name: @serealfurst
Comment: There is a recent metanalysis of studies regarding Cannabinoids and how each one effects sleep and while its been known for a long time that THC affects REM sleep there is now evidence to suggest that CBD in combination with THC effects not only REM but also N3 (deep) sleep. Deep sleep is the stage in which a lot of the muscle repair and physical rejuvenation occurs. More evidence is needed on the effects of CBD regarding sleep but we can extrapolate from this data that adding CBD to an already altered THC sleeping pattern may actually worsen instead of improve it. I think this is important to mention because many daily THC users I know turn to adding CBD on top of their habit (to alleviate negative side effects such as sleep issues or anxiety) instead of taking a break from their usage. It seems to help some people at first but most people I see go through it (myself included) end up with noticeably worse sleep in the long run. I'm off both Weed and CBD now and although the first month was hell I'm sleeping MUCH better now.

Name: @ItsASuckyName
Comment: For anyone thinking about smoking weed: I was stuck in a bubble and pushed away anyone who even made the slightest comment about me smoking weed. I had no idea I was such a pain to be around and that it had changed my behavior. There was no way for anyone to get me out of it, because I could not see that I was stuck. The only way was to ride it out until it went completely wrong. Losing my friends was the least of my problems compared to the mental health issues weed caused me, and I still have to deal with that 11 years later. It is always good to share the personal downsides of drugs, because the people who say that it is nothing but positive, will scream the loudest and ignore the people spiraling out of control in the process. It is such a big risk for undiagnosed people...which can be anyone. Sure it can have positive effects for certain people, but don't gamble on it. If you or any direct family have mental health issues, than don't just start doing drugs. Take this from someone with schizophrenia and other psychosis related problems triggered because of weed.

Name: @markgriskey
Comment: I suffer from insomnia and other debilitating sleep issues that have plagued me my whole life. My mother actually sent me to afternoon preschool because my circadian rhythm was so severely delayed. School sucked. I never adjusted. Then in my fist year of college I took all night classes, and suddenly became a straight A student. I would normally sleep from 3 am to about noon and felt great. But the rest of the world doesn‚Äôt work that way. Then as I got older, things got worse I could no longer sleep in and my sleep was very fragmented ( wake up after 3 hours then twiddle my thumbs for a couple hours then sleep another 3 hours) then medical pot became legal in CA, and it was like a miracle cure. Would imbibe in the evening and had gummies or vape available if I woke up in the middle of the night. I would get 8 hours of sleep! But yes, my rem sleep was impacted. It was still better to get enough sleep instead of the horrible insomnia/ fragmented sleep. But then! I devolved a horrible condition called CHS. Look it up. It sucks! So I had to give up cannabis and now I‚Äôm a wreck. The rebound effect was awful and now I‚Äôm taking prescription sleep meds as well as anything over the counter I can find (melatonin/ valerian root etc) unfortunately these meds can also effect sleep quality and I don‚Äôt get enough (5 to six hours of fragmented sleep) many doctors are unsympathetic and I am really struggling. Anyway I enjoyed your article. Please check out CHS ‚ÄúCannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome‚Äù and do a video about that condition, it‚Äôs apparently related to your genetic makeup, and many chronic users will never develop it, but ‚Äúlucky me‚Äù I am basically unable to use cannabis long term. I‚Äôm suspecting my insomnia has a genetic root and am hoping to find the magic combination of supplements that will get me back on track (and yes, I eat a healthy diet, get regular exercise, avoid caffeine late in the day etc) it‚Äôs a real bummer that I can‚Äôt use pot for sleep anymore.

Name: @markhoward5628
Comment: Ok, here's my experience. I had been smoking weed for about 30+ years...soon as I got home from work, straight to the kitchen, kettle on tin out, skin up. I'd have about 5-6 spliffs  (3 skinner) every night on weekdays. Weekends. Double it.....at least. I gave up weed/cigs last June/July & quit, using patches. Having given up cigs (not weed) back in 2010, I knew the side effects of leaving patches on whilst sleeping. The dreams were as vivid and random as anything I can remember. Bearing that in mind, I never kept the patches on when going to bed this time round. Ever since giving up, I have at LEAST 2 dreams a night that are bizarre and as real as I'm typing this. They ALWAYS wake me up. It's gotten to the stage where I want to go back to smoking green again so i can get a decent night's sleep. I've gone from 63kgs to 75kgs ! Still eating crap, so the munchies has never left me. Bank balance is healthier (used to buy an oz a month + cigs). Stress levels are through the roof. I really, really, really miss it.

Name: @lionessathena8679
Comment: Like another commenter, I've been a chronic insomniac (almost) my entire life - since age 20, I'm now 46. Was a sleep walker as a kid and never could nap. Years of research and investigation, including sleep studies, have never revealed cause or cure. Have tried everything, including behavioral and habit changes, many pharmaceuticals and supplements and herbs. Some of these things have the opposite effect on me - examples are Nyquil, trazadone, and valerian root. Benzos help a lot but they are terrible for your health, especially long term - never going down that road again. Eating low carb helps me some. But the only thing that consistently allows me to get some sleep is cannabis. I have no need to increase my dose, only need to switch strains periodically. I don't take breaks. I find it's certain terpenes that do the trick. I do go through periods of waking up frequently and that is very frustrating, but it comes and goes. A good night is only one or two wake ups with minimal difficulty getting back to sleep. (Just slept through the night - glorious! - that only happens about once a year these days.) I didn't dream much for many years when I took gabapentin, but since quitting that pharmaceutical I dream again. I find deep sleep is what I need the most and struggle to get when sleeping poorly. I do take pharmaGABA (naturally fermented form of the neurotransmitter GABA) and that also helps, but I have to take a big dose for any effect - 1000mg. I don't like feeling dependent on substances to sleep, but the alternative is not sleeping at all and that is terrifying, a viscous cycle, and terrible for short and long term health.

Name: @koransky1
Comment:
I started using edibles when I was told that I would need to start chemo for breast cancer.  I had seen how my parents suffered through cancer, and swore if I ever got it, I was going to use it.

Turned out that it helped me deal much, much better with treatment.  I didn't get nauseated, I didn't lose my appetite, and I could finally sleep - three things many people on chemo struggle with.  I figured giving up dreaming so I could still rack up some z's was worth it - and I haven't changed my mind on that.  I still take it nightly to deal with the pain of hormone blockers (I will have to take them for five years, got four more to go....). 

It didn't cure my cancer, it just made the treatments that did cure it tolerable.

Does opposite for me keeps me up at night, even tried CBD with THC that is made for sleep, what works for one person doesn‚Äôt necessarily work for another. 

I worked in the Sleep medicine field and have done probably a hundred MSLT‚Äôs which are 5 naps (4 naps would be given if patient was taking very long to fall asleep or not sleeping at all) given during the day after the patient spends the night at our Sleep facility so we know they slept at least the minimum required hours, so we know they are not sleepy during the day from lack of sleep. These tests were done to determine if someone has narcolepsy or for other reasons, many times it was done so the patient could be prescribed a drug like Provigil, which is an expensive drug to keep people alert during the day.

Name: @inaliFTW
Comment: It's nice to finally see people talking about what cannabis actually does. 30 year user here o7. I typically take breaks every few months and a big break every few years. What people also don't talk about is digestion. As I get older, when I start using weed again, the "munchies" actually are just a giant influx of new calories and food digestion compared to what you're used to. So it can cause digestion issues, constipation, dehydration from all those things you consume that your body isn't used to. This only lasts a few months and then I think cannabis actually suppresses my desire to over eat, which I do quite a bit off thc.

Am I getting quality sleep?

I personally was smoking every night after college alone because I was bored and trying to avoid deep difficult feelings of grief - dumb I know. Name: @espinoth9913
Comment:
My REM sleep was actually more or less dead for years before I started doing weed (or at least I couldn't every remember a lick of any dreams), but after I started doing weed, it reawakened my ability to have dreams anytime I ever don't do it before bed or take a tolerance break.
I also have a microsensitivity to THC, so it barely takes much at all to get me high in the first place. When I do take it before bed, the feeling in the morning is familiar, which sort of confirms my thinking that my ability to dream was somehow inert for years.
But then I of course feel really energized when I wake up after not doing weed now, and have incredible dream recall. Because of my own experiences, I kinda think it might be worth researching off-and-on cannabis microdosing as a treatment for people already suffering from any sort of existing REM deficiency.

I started cutting back last week and have already started noticing an improvement in my sleep, vis a vis, I‚Äôm able to actually fall asleep properly now, and stay asleep longer.

Now I just smoke every once in awhile throughout the day, and have been avoiding smoking at least two hours before bed time.

Comment: I‚Äôve found the best solution for sleep is delta-8 + CBN edibles, just before bed. My biggest insomnia problem isn‚Äôt getting to sleep, but rather staying asleep. The edibles help considerably with that. Delta-9 rather than delta-8 tends to wake up the brain a bit. I average just over 7 hours of sleep a night. More important than cannaboids, though I find that the key to getting enough sleep is a consistent bedtime (that gives you enough time to sleep before getting up before work/school/kids/etc), and a strict shutdown routine so you‚Äôre ready to fall asleep when you go to bed. In other words, putting down your phone for an hour before bed is probably more useful and important than THC/CBD! Not eating snacks at bedtime, not playing video games‚Ä¶ pay close attention to any stimulation in the last hour before bed, and cut it if it‚Äôs keeping you awake!

Everything in moderation. ‚úå

Name: @jake.notfromstatefarm
Comment:
Whatever your thoughts on CBD, you should know that on its own (i.e. isolated from THC), CBD is inert, or inactive. A small amount of THC is needed to "activate" the CBD, and that's part of why dispensaries offer various ratios in their CBD products. It doesn't have to be a psychoactive dose. Below that threshold, it's called a therapeutic dose. It's not enough to get anyone high, but it _is_ enough to get the cannabidiol working. Without THC to catalyze it, it won't work. CBD products from places that aren't allowed to sell THC do not contain any and are ineffective. 

Source: I'm a five-year cannabis industry veteran, Oregon & California.

Name: @StatikV87
Comment: Since I was a little kid, I always had trouble falling asleep, staring at the ceiling for hours before drifting off.  I would also regularly have crazy lucid dreams. It was found that I actually had a very restricted airway causing sleep apnea which would sporadically have me wake myself up.  After getting my tonsils & adenoids out, I'd be waking up less in the middle of the night and thus it ended up that I would remember lucid dreams less frequently.  I was feeling more rested, but was disappointed I didn't remember as many cool dreams.  For about 10 years now, I've averaged smoking probably 1/5 gram or so per night close to bed time.  It is in place of having a cocktail before bed like some folks do, had positive impacts on my depression/anxiety, and helped me fall asleep fast.  However, I have barely remembered any dreams in the last decade.  Surprisingly, my tolerance hasn't gone up much, still being able to benefit from 1-3 decent hits.  Either way, I am between jobs at the moment and not buying/smoking weed.  I dealt with a stretch of insomnia when I first ran out, but things are slowly seeming to normalize.  Hoping I start getting more quality REM sleep and maybe the cool lucid dreams will come back as a result.  Cheers.

Name: @evanledge
Comment:
hey man im high, here's what i know:

eat a mango, smoke a bowl. you get higher. terpenes. myrcene specifically. terpenes are found in all kinds of plants...mangoes, citrus, pepper, etc. not just cannabis. each strain has its own "signature" of terpene presence and amount. it is also a heavy factor in how each strain smells. Myrcene is also found in basically all cannabis strains, hence why eating a mango and "generally" smoking weed works to strengthen your high. indica strains TEND to be heavy with myrcene, while Sativas TEND to not. (they still got it tho)

terpenes are the oils in the buds and plant matter centered around the trichomes. theres alot of different terpenes, so its hard to list them out. my favorite is Terpinoline, because it amplifies the effects of the other terpenes around it. its the "volume knob" terpene! the crystals you always see when you shine a light on a bud are the concentrations of cannabinoids (THC, CBD, etc) terpenes are why you need humidity control (along with the grind quality and other physical parts of smoking) with humidity and time comes mold, so be cautious! (hint: boveda packs are dope!)

now go buy pure THCa (unheated THC) isolate (as in isolated from the rest of the source material...its pure thc) and add that to your bowl instead of eating a mango before hand. still a strong effect, pretty different feeling though.

now go buy a vape. if its a distillate, its going to have less terpenes, but super high THC content. if its a live resin (or some variation) cartridge, it has a lot MORE terpenes in it, and a drop in THC content (still higher thc then the strongest flower tho) 

Edibles don't really have terpenes in them, but the maker of those edibles can add supplemental cannabinoids. your label on the package (in a legal state) should list the amounts of THC, THCa, CBD, CBN, CBG, and CBC (sometimes). if you dont see added cannabinoids, your just eating gummy, flavored, THC...regardless of indica, sativa, or hybrid words/colors on the package. each cannabinoid does different things to your body. CBD is more for pain management,  and relaxation. CBN is more sedative, and used commonly in my area as a "nighttime" cannabinoid. CBG and CBC are described as mood boosters and motivation enhancements (energy but not in a caffiene way) but i forgot which one is which.

 ill be straight up...theres more and more variations of THC being found...i only trust THC and THCa (same thing, except one hasnt been heated yet). theres discussions about whether Delta9THC and THC are the same things, i have no opinion...i dont know. i do know Delta8THC is not found in the cannabis your meant to consume. there are things like "Industrial Hemp" used for more of its physical properties, that Delta8THC can be found in, but it doesnt really function like a THC molecule in your body. its much weaker feeling. 

so take all this knowledge, and apply it. combine your terpenes, your strains! look online at the terpene profiles of your favorite (smokeable) flower! take edibles with just THC, then take edibles with added CBD, then see what CBG feels like, then! eat an edible and then smoke after! That entire adventure is you seeing what the "Entourage Effect" is. combining different amounts of terpenes and cannabinoids, low thc, high thc. see what you as an individual prefers. take interest in whats been helping you out so much!

if you don't live in a legal area, then you don't know what your smoking unless you grew it yourself, and even then....where'd you get the seed? be thankful your able to get high, and have a trustworthy source. im not knocking that life. up until recently that WAS my life.

if you do live in a legal area, then all of these little experiments should be possible, and i hope your off on a journey to find what works for you.

this was made with the help of a bowl of Wedding Cake <3

Name: @bobparkes2493
Comment: I have tourettes syndrome. Its to this day, even by the people who have it, it is enormously misunderstood. In the one session I have had with a tourettes professional in my life he described it like this- when you have tourettes, the neurons and signals in your brain basically move so much and so frequently that many signals will often end up in the completely wrong place or be sent with 0 intention of them ever happening. which explains tics very well, but also does a great job to explain why most people with tourettes would probably also testify to: having terrible handwriting, having more energy than makes sense, mentally and physically, not being able to keep particular thought processes in your brain for extended periods of time, not being able to sleep because you cannot clear your head or do anything during that day that will bring your energy down. i think I can genuinely say that for the first 11 years of my life I never slept more than 4 hours in a night, and despite that never ending lack of sleep, every day and I woke and had enough energy to share with every human on the planet to run a marathon each and still have some left over. and I promise there is absolutely 0 over exaggeration in that statement. bedtime was torture for me. having to be alone with my thoughts in complete darkness for up to 3-4 hours at a time with more energy than I even knew what to do with when I was awake. let alone trying to sleep, was complete torture. when I got diagnosed at the age of 11, I got melatonin tablets to help me with my sleep, and they did, I could actually reliably goto sleep and wake up at similar times, but it still wasn't great. When I got to uni, I still never knew what it was like to get real regernative sleep. I was against the idea of weed for a long time because of my biological fathers own issues with substance abustnace, but eventually I gave it a try and the change in my life was astounding. It finally let me slow all the processes in my brain down, I could relax, spend time thinking and reflecting on things for extended periods of time. The change in my life has been indescribable. I actually started getting real, consistent sleep, and my body started to feel what that was like, the differences it made to my emotions and mental clarity. Alongside this, since I could now concentrate, I had time to reflect on the way I was living my life, thinking about how lucky I was to have the things I do and be where I was, the depression I thought I was suffering from is gone. I eliminated all the bad things from my life like my video game and pornogrophy addictions, processed food reliance, started working out consistently and making real friendships and deep connections with people, and above all else my tics and side affects of my touettes were oblitereated, not just while i was high, but now I've learnt what it feels like to slow my brain down, and sorted out all the other issues in my life, the significance and struggle with my tics is a fraction of what it used to be. I now sleep everyday with no weed or tablets or assistance within 30 minutes of going to bed. for the first time in my life i can dream multiple times a night and remember what happened. All of the amazing things i have now in my life, as well as the things i had before but didn't realise. I attribute it all to the help i received as a result of smoking marijuana. For me, at least, it truly was a miracle drug, and it saved my life. And its affects were so paramount, and affected me so deeply, that despite my love for it, i no longer even need it, and i have learnt to have the self control to say no to these things, and instead enjoy them on occasion. Regardless of the fact i now consume it much less, i will be forever grateful for its effects on me and the lessons i learnt as a result of it. Many of the conservative old heads in my family have completely changed their view on it as a result of seeing and hearing about the way it changed me. the difference in person i am now to 2 years ago a little while before i discovered it is so night and day. One of the most important things i ever did in my life was having that first toke, and beggining that journey.

Name: @alexwilcox9559
Comment:
Just about at week 3 of no use. I smoked pretty much daily from the age of 17-27. I just kind of thought about it one day, realizing I've spent more of the last decade of my free time stoned rather than sober, and it just kinda hurt me. I had essentially forgotten what going to bed sober was like, as I told myself I needed weed to sleep, which was true at that point. I was just perpetually tired, and my head felt foggy constantly. It began affecting my performance at work. My superiors didn't notice anything, but I certainly did. I personally felt stupid which I know I'm not, and I just wanted something to change in my life. I decided to quit for at least 8 weeks, and then afterwards determine what I would do from there.

What I can say so far is that my sleep has dramatically improved. The first week without it absolutely sucked, as I would lay awake in bed for hours before falling asleep and I missed being okay with boredom, especially in the winter. But after duking it out for the first week, I'm actually waking up in the morning and not having issues getting out of bed, or for sleeping 9 plus hours. It's already allowed me to find other things to keep me busy, rather than just getting stoned and playing video games by myself. 

I'm not knocking at people who consume it daily, as it would be extremely hypocritical of me to do so, but I do encourage people to try and take a break. You might surprise yourself on how much more you can get done in a day, and how you actually can begin to fall asleep quickly again without it. Plus, your short term memory will insanely improve. I know it's not going to be my last time ever using it, but I do want to make it my last time consuming it by myself, and without being in a social setting.

You've given me a lot to think about, poor sleep is my single biggest health concern (as poor sleep amplifies all my other issues) and cannabis has been my most reliable anti anxiety / anti depressant / sleep aid for years, but if all those withdrawal symptoms are from a lack of healthy REM sleep I need to think long and hard about the road ahead.

Name: @PsycHoOone
Comment:
Nice video! The rebound-thing is interesting, because I have reeeaally bad phases when I don't have sth to smoke (illegal here, no direct contact, not much money, etc), but in most cases those where times of really high stress, too. In general weed helps me to stay away from alcohol and yes, I pick sleeping at all over a hand full of nights of sleeping objectively good :D
Falling asleep for me -> problematic. Ultra realistic, energy consuming dreams -> problematic. Waking up regularly at Night, mostly not just once -> problematic. Not getting out of bed due to depression and ending up sleeping (with interruptions) for like 12-14+h a day -> problematic.
So yeah, for me in my personal experience, smoking helps with all of these problems and even though I do feel off/dazed/not that fit sometimes too, it's really not worse than the regular depression lol.
(This is 100% subjective, handle drugs with care, stop the use immediately if they make you feel bad in any way!)

Name: @andrewgowens1175
Comment: Started at 16 I am 33. This video is very helpful. I've had sleep issues since I was a kid being prescribed seroquel and then later trazadone. Started smoking weed daily and started getting the best sleep of my life or so I thought. About 3 ¬Ω to 4 years ago I noticed that if I didn't have it I didn't sleep like for days until I got more I'm not exaggerating. Side note I do construction and have since I was 17  so I'm definitely exerting a lot of energy and would feel very tired at night but would not sleep. I  have taken 2 benadryl and up to 40 milligrams of melatonin at the same to try and sleep and still wouldn't. Weed and alcohol where the only things that would work. Drank every night for the past 10 years also. About 3 years ago. I had an overnight very dramatic permanent change in my vision which turned out not to be a big deal but for the two weeks I had to wait until I found that out I went through alot mentally and emotionally as I wondered if something was wrong with me and  was I going to die? who would take care of my three young kids? That day in October of 2020 I repented of my sins and put my faith in Jesus Christ and became his disciple. The Bible says there's nothing wrong with having a drink sometimes. Jesus did and the bible says there will be new wine in heaven Isiah 25:6 (if God is making it its probably some good stuff, aparently when Jesus made wine at that wedding it was way better than what men had made)  I also am grateful God gave us the marijuana plant it does have some wonderful medical properties, not sure we should smoke it though it's not good for the lungs and it does have a high potential for abuse. Over the past 3 years I have tried off and on to quit because i felt thats what God wanted me to do as i prayed and yet couldn't because of the lack of sleep. After praying about it I've let drinking and smoking  go and can sleep with a minimal amount of melatonin and some low milligram gummies, which I have been working towards weening myself off of those as well as I have been taking less and less. Name: @seedystudios
Comment: I began using cannabis not only to deal with chronic pain but also my also my anxiety and regular (almost nightly) night terrors. I used to wake up in the middle of the night from horrific dreams that combined painful memories and the sensation of physical pain, which shook me to my core. After several years of chronic, daily use my overall sleep quality did decrease: 6 hours of rest on the regular and lethargy during the day. I've been taking a month break now, and my dreams are wild! My anxiety is better now (something I've been working at with therapy, exercise, and other things). My latest dream, I was speaking and understanding Spanish-- I can't do that while I'm awake! The dreams are so vivid and nightly, it's insane. I can also fall asleep sooner and I'm sleeping up to 9 hours. Happy to report that the night terrors haven't returned.

PTSD, pain management,  and a very few other finite medical conditions may be the few exceptions.  Addressing all the many reasons a person can't sleep before turning to a drug is always the preffered choice.  But it takes more effort and resolve from the patient.  Esp anything that develops a tolerance over time, that's a red flag it's not ideal for the body/mind.  But as long as the business is bringing in millions of dollars, it will touted as the answer.  Period.  Alcohol will also solve many of those issues.  But its on the negative marketing side now, pot is making tins of cash and now on the positive side, soniys being pushed.  And what person who doesn't enjoy smoking pot isn't going to rejoice that their drug of abuse is being touted as the ultimate answer.  Duh. Thats where the marketing. ones in.  Alcohol and heroine also lessen anxiety, reduce PTSD symptoms, etc, but that doesn't make them the solution.  But since marijuana is less destructive than those, it gets a free pass as being beneficial, preferred, the panacea answer.  We, as a species, will always gravitate towards a quick fix approach that requires little to no effort on our parts.  Again, marketing LOVES that about us.

Name: @SantiagoHernandez-bj3mb

As a Veteran, turning to cannabis for my depression and anxiety has been great as I just did not like SSRI‚Äôs and the list of effects it had on me personally. I never personally struggled with sleep so this was never an issue for me, but I do agree a tolerance break is good. 

I think we often also overlook other contributing factors that affect sleep like stress, alcohol, caffeine consumption, diet, level of fitness, etc that also play a role. I‚Äôm also weary of studies conducted in the US due to its aggressive lobbying by pharmaceutical companies that are trying to create  paranoia around Marijuana. Always look for biases in studies and where they are getting their funding from. Has the research been corroborated and by who? Etc. not saying Marijuana is without faults, but misinformation is everywhere. Bottom line enjoy it responsibly, know your medical history and how it personally affects you.

Name: @mwaltrip
Comment: I took a course on Cannabis Research on Coursera and learned that it is incredibly difficult to conduct scientific studies on the effects of Cannabis in the US because of the Controlled Substance Act of 1972. Marijuana is a schedule 1 drug, along with the most dangerous and controlled substances of all like heroin. By contrast, Fetanyl is schedule 2. It's a shame because Cannabis is so widely used and we don't know very much about the effects on humans, good or bad.

Name: @buzzdb66
Comment: I've had insomnia issues basically my entire adult life. Some nights I would be lucky to get 3 hours of sleep and I would probably wake up twice during those 3 hours, so I definitely wasn't getting any REM sleep. I used to smoke a lot of weed in my teens, but then stopped for almost a decade because it started giving me bad panic attacks and anxiety at the time. Now that weed is recreationally legal in my state I've started buying low dose thc gummies and eating 20-30mg of thc before bed each night. Edibles are much more gentle to me because of the gradual come up, and 20-30mg is a small enough dose where I almost never get anxious. The positive effect on my sleeping habits has been insane though. Instead of tossing and turning for 2 hours before falling asleep each night, I can pretty much lay down, close my eyes and be asleep in 5 minutes. I also stay asleep for 7-8 hours. It's amazing and I feel so much better these days since I'm not sleep deprived 24/7. I've been doing this nightly for about 2 years now. When my tolerance starts going up a bit, I just reduce the dose to 10mg nightly for a couple weeks and my tolerance goes back down. The gummies I get are really cheap too, it only costs me about $1.00-$1.50 worth each night. I'm insanely thankful to be able to get these now since they have been such a drastic help. Not being able to sleep is such a frustrating issue to go through and you feel terrible all the time. It's definitely worth trying for people with similar problems, and it doesn't leave me a groggy zombie for hours in the morning like sleeping pills do.

Name: @paulhpxinc
Comment:
First off - excellent summary of the existing research! I‚Äôm in healthcare, always doing research, and I know many doctors that have missed points you are bringing up, such as dosage dependent tolerance. 

I want to add an important point, and maybe get your response - my reading on sleep studies seemed to indicate that marijuana can actually promote positive effects on sleep for the first week of use. And then, after that, it is much like you said. So, if this is true, then the question becomes what would the effect of cycling use or intermittent usage be? I am hopeful that it could mean better sleep quality, assuming the user can practice this level of self control.

Name: @Sheilanagig
Comment: With PTSD you get nightmares. THC prevents you from entering the sleep stage where you would have those vivid dreams. Instead you keep it to the sleep stage just before REM and you have routine dreams, daily impressions, but no nightmares. In the balance, you're getting sleep and not having nightmares at the expense of some of your sleep quality. Half a loaf is better than none, because if you're not sleeping at all, your mental state tends to deteriorate faster. It becomes a negative feedback loop. So it's a tradeoff.

Name: @PhilipPedro2112
Comment:
Cannabis generally intensifies whatever I am experiencing. If I am exhausted and I smoke, I can fall asleep rapidly and awake fully rested. But normally, for the first hour or two after smoking, I enter a state of mental excitement similar to being on amphetamine that gradually declines and becomes one of calm and sedation. During that initial stage, increased thought makes sleep almost impossible. I may not recall any dreams or may, near the end of a full sleep cycle, awake from a dream. I do notice that when withdrawal from chronic use, I have intense and numerous dreams in a night's sleep.
I believe maybe something in cannabis is performing the action found in REM sleep, making the brain's need for REM unnecessary. 
I'm 59 and have smoked since the age of 14 with several breaks in usage lasting from 1 to 6 months with no noticeable effects other than a baseline boredom with daily life. I've never regretted smoking and hope I never have cause to.

Name: @dannynannady
Comment:
100% with you all the way. Here's the big take away from this guys comment.
If your life gets better (more energy/motivation etc.) after taking a break from weed...  then maybe you should take a look at yourself and consider quitting.

I've been smoking for a long time and one thing that a lot of weed smokers don't realize  is how complacent it makes you. You may not realize it until it's too late.
Missed calls or appointments that could have led to some doors opening for you... Conversations/calls that could have probably lead to friendships/relationships or whatever it might be... 
But they all passed you by without you taking appropriate action because of the weed clouding your mind/judgement.
I honestly would never recommend smoking weed to young people or young adults as it can really influence what direction your life goes and in my experience it is usually in a bad or worse direction.
Weed is a lot more insidious than a lot of young people believe, take it from someone that has been smoking for 15+ years...

But I'm not here to preach. To each his own man, just putting my 2 cents out there. Maybe someone might read this one day and maybe gain a new perspective.
Peace.

Name: @dannynannady
Comment:
@@m.c.t3471 
You are in the minority. Most daily weed smokers do NOT have great paying jobs, work out regularly etc.
You are literally the 1-2% of weed smokers. 
But hey, don't let me stop you. I'm kinda jealous actually. I wish I could smoke weed all day and still be active/productive.
All I'm saying is that your experience is NOT representative of 98-99% of daily weed smokers and it's important that people (especially young people) realize this.

Source: I know a LOT of daily weed smokers.

Name: @Cococonutt
Comment: The narrative that weed is harmless, non-addicting, withdrawal free and will fix all of your ailments is something that I fed into 7 years ago. 7 years later I went from ambitious, social, healthy to fat, homeless, socially awkward with no friends and poor relationships with my family. Eventually I forget what it felt like to be sober and being high was the only normal. People begin to notice, non-smokers don‚Äôt want to be around you, you lose respect and quality friendships. But the only thing that mattered was the next high, when I could escape and just chill. It was so easy to ignore my problems, ignore bills, ignore messages, ignore goals, ignore my future, just light up a joint and put it off to tomorrow. One day I woke up and realized I had nothing to show for the last 7 years, no quality memories, no real friendships, no achievements, no goals met, time melted away, I wasn‚Äôt present, I was high, escaping off to nowhere. Nowhere wasn‚Äôt my plan. For years I wanted to quit, the longest I ever went was a month but usually it was just a few hours before I was right back to being high and giving up. Now I am trying to climb out of the hole I dug for 7 years. I‚Äôm sure this comment will feel like a buzz kill but I wish someone would have really told me how bad it could get.

I had about 2 weeks of shit sleep, but then my body got back into the natural sleep cycle, and it helped massively!! From that point I decided to still smoke, but now and then when at a party or at a festival etc Daily smoking zaps you of motivation, BIG STYLE. Use it when needed that's what I do, although I have been daily smoking since I lost my Dad. Time to go back to the 'every now and then' style for me.

Name: @ry1255
Comment: agree 100%~ was a THC smoker since I was 24 EVERY NIGHT (yes, every night) due to intense insomnia since I was 18. Was on sleeping meds but quit because it made me a zombie. At 24, my buddy told me to try weed to sleep. Tried it 1st time and had the best sleep ever. I'm 36 now, and since Oct of last year, my tolerance got way too high (no pun intended) to the point where the weed wasn't helping me sleep anymore. Of course, I was petrified of quitting because the weed was a maricle for my insomnia since 24. All my insomnia fears came back and hit me hard AF my first 5 days of qutting (literally, NO SLEEP, was the most mental torture those 5-6 days of no sleep). Fast forward to now, I am no longer a slave to needing weed (nor ANY substance) to help me sleep. I give my thanks/gratitude to my sleep coach from the sleep coach school YouTube channel, Daniel Erichsen, for curing my insomnia fears. I took my first toke a few weekends ago (not for sleep, but just wanted to chillax) and GOLLY it felt like the first time again. I now smoke a few hits on the weekends, and all I need is 1 hit to get me there, and I always knock out eventually lol. Also, my dreams have been intense but I really enjoy remembering most of my dreams. When I was a nightly smoker, I didn't remember ANY dreams. I didn't know what it felt like to wake up feeling refreshed vs. getting 6+ hours of sleep on weed and wake up feeling tired/groggy still... Additionally, I really like how I have more energy now (even on nights that I lack sleep). My short term memory has also came back 10 fold and I don't need to re-read things over and over to comprehend (when I used to smoke nightly, I didn't do it all day; it was mainly smoking at night time but tolerance got way too high). I also don't overeat anymore and mentally sharper and stronger at the gym (gym rat for 20 years). Weed is a medicine, and just like any medicine, if one takes it regularly and/or abuse it, tolerance will get ridiculous and the "magic" will dissapate. I'm  so happy that I stopped and now if I want to smoke, I do it as a way to relax vs. praying that it will help me sleep. It is definitely a maricle medicine from Mama Earth, but can't abuse it, just like everything and anything.

Name: @icestationzebraassociates2460
Comment:
I can definitely confirm the affect on REM sleep, HOWEVER:

(keep in mind this is just personal experience)

I have started using legally available farm bill THCA flower. THCA is a precursor to delta 9 (and a component of regular old weed - in fact, it is one of the major measures of good weed - the percentage of THCA is usually labeled along with d9 percentage in states where cannabis is legally available.) and is not psychoactive until you put flame to it. I have noticed that since then, I have dreams again. It _could_ be that certain terpenes are responsible for the detrimental sleep effects and they're not present in THCA flower. I do not know, but since it's legally available, would recommend giving it a shot and seeing if your situation doesn't improve.

It works the same and, imho (27 year smoker - usually daily) is actually better. There's a little place called Greenlight Natural that ships and it's no more expensive than black market...just a little tidbit.

Comment: I'm a medical cannabis patient treating depression, Bipolar, anxiety and PTSD. I've been experimenting with the individual cannabinoids currently being sold online and have discovered that each cannabinoid has its own properties that treat different ailments. For example, THC is very effective for treating depression yet I find high doses cause anxiety. On the flip I found CBD seems more effective treating anxiety. Shockingly I discovered that by using only THCA instead of a full cannabis extract the appetite stimulation typically created from cannabis is absent. As a result I've managed to lose nearly 100lbs that I've accumulated over all the years I've been self medicating with cannabis flower. We need to further research so we can continue learning more about these cannabinoids by doing so I'm convinced we can eliminate the negative effects and increase the positive effects of these cannabinoids to more safely treat many different medical conditions. Last count I heard was at 114 different cannabinoids have been discovered. Less than 20 are available to the public so far. Much more to learn with this amazing plant. It absolutely has medicinal value! The future looks bright with cannabis!

Name: @Tiedyeman
Comment: As a person that experiences night terrors, less REM sleep is a blessing. The quality of my sleep is much improved by THC, along with the quality of life and my continued existence. Cannabis not only gives me better sleep, but keeps me from needing opioids or other pain killers. It has also caused an unsightly mole on my eyelid to disappear completely and eliminated the arthritis pain in a finger completely as well as shrinking the swollen knuckle back to nearly it's original size. I find tolerance to be a myth in my personal experience, I do not need to keep increasing the amount I use. I have never experienced "negative" effects from cannabis other than the misunderstanding and intolerance of other people.

Comment:
Thought I‚Äôd give my experience. I‚Äôve been smoking since I was about 14 (25 now). Here in New Zealand you aren‚Äôt able to always pick what you get Indica or Sativa, ya take what you can get. I‚Äôve been an every day smoker for so long, definitely the last 3 years. I‚Äôm on day 26 without smoking ‚Ä¶. Good lord the dreams are wild but the sleeps are amazing. I found that the biggest help was that when I stopped I was with a friend that didn‚Äôt smoke and I was being incredibly active for the first 6 days. Each night when it was time for bed, sleep came easy as I was physically tired. I highly recommend making sure you are tired enough to not even think about having a smoke to help you sleep, be busy! 
I think a big reason I wanted to stop was due to my memory, low quality to say the least. 
I love the smell of green and am not fussed whether I do it again I just want to not rely on it as I have done. Funny thing is I‚Äôve found myself feeling high/drunk often even though I am very sober ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

Name: @thetallerindian7031
Comment: So as a user for over 8 years now, I'd like to break some stigmas and probably send you to the right path regarding weed. First, quitting any kind of addictive substance is the best solution but some of you just want it in your life just like me. I've been there chasing a better weed high and consuming more each day. But it's not really the key. Chasing a bigger high will lead you to do just that in your everyday life. What I do now is smoke half a joint a day and that does it for me. I can focus on everything else and I can enjoy my preferred form of recreation a lot more. I got dreams too. I sleep for 7 to 8 hours a night and everything's just right. So, I'd encourage everyone to do this. If you use a bong daily just use it for 2 hits everyday. And if you're into edibles, just know one thing. Unless the amount of weed used in the cookie is really low, you'll feel the high from an edible a lot longer than smoking it. So even though smoking is the unhealthy process, the high is a lot more manageable and practical. Also, NEVER drive while high. Be responsible, and if you've got to drive right now, don't consume it. Give yourself atleast 2 to 3 hours after consuming it before you drive. If you're at the early stages of smoking it give yourself about 7-8 hours before driving. Please be responsible with your weed and hopefully we can literally give the world a lesson that potheads can be responsible with their weed. Criminalizing it was a big bad move for the world and now, with the help of the internet we can teach people worldwide to be responsible with it.

Name: @i.k.8868
Comment: I think you should have explained more clearly the relationship between REM sleep/dreams, and memory. People who suffer from PTSD are able to cope with life because THC helps them block parts of their memory. During the day it helps them stay calm and focus on the task at hand, while at night it dampens the nightmares. That is why so many people take it just to get through life. But the flip side is that people who take THC daily are much less able to form new long term memories, which are needed to deal with traumatic emotions such as grief or guilt. Your dreams are a way to compress your experiences of the past few weeks/months into a single (or a few) long term memories. Like a very crude summary or diary. This compression, while painful, also turns the subjective experience into a more abstract, distant event. It is like a .rar file being written and read at the same time. That is why time moves so much faster in your dream world. So for people suffering from PTSD, THC can help them to be able to function on a daily basis, but they are not being treated. They need Psychotherapy or some other therapy to get over their trauma. THC and trauma therapy don't go well together. Smoking weed is a temporary solution, and if you become dependent on it, you should seek professional help. Because in the long run, it is worth it remembering the moment you fell in love, had a baby, or even just what subjects you studied half a year ago.

Name: @AlonsoArayaAudiovisual
Comment:
heyy what a great video. felt identified every minute. 

My case is....I've been smoking daily for almost 4 years. I'm 36 now. II had a six month break at the beginning of this year. And now I'm going through a week of withdrawal so my experience is fresh. 

I sleep 9 hours  on weekends. During the week not less than 6 and not more than 7 hours. I have always had difficulties falling sleep. Too much intrusive thoughts and I am a very anxious person. But after I started using sleeping inductor pills, this was kind of fixed. But...if I had a very difficult day, even with the pill I had trouble falling asleep, so I found that smoking kinda enhanced the effect of the sleeping aid pill. But there is a catch, If a smoke a small dose, it activates me, my brain and fall asleep later than I wanted. So I have to smoke a lot now. 

I have been smoking 2-3 joints a day.  After work. I think it's a lot. I started with 1/3 of a joint per day in 2020.   Before this, I was a ocational user of marihuana.  Once or twice per week.  Since 2017. And before that, in college, just a few times a year. Say 10 times.  

Also, like the video explained, I have troble increasing my temperature in the morning. I suffer from depression too, and marihuana can increase some of the efffects of depression like a low body temperature. Or even cause more anxiety sometimes and more intrusive thoughts. 

I am starting to realize that at the long run, it is better not to depend on anything external. Your body has it's own chemical factory  and it's wise. But sometimes, like myself, lacked of something in the brain before the use of marihuana, and that made me use it in the first place. Dopamine realease and other quemical reactions that my brain was lacking. But I think that the best solution nowadays is psycological  therapy and sometimes some pill. (I think pharmaceutical as bad as they are, I think they have developed very advanced human technology. With just a small dose of some drug you can have very substantial effects on our lives. 

  But I think we should still use drugs like marihuana, mushrooms, LSD, etc,  bit more in a ritualistic way. In some festivities, special ocations, maybe with some intention or purpose.  Like when we open a bottle of wine. 

Cheers to everyone, and wish you good smoke.

Comment: In my teens I developed insomnia. Always had issues falling asleep. Once I was asleep I didn‚Äôt want to get up. Around the age of 20 at a party I was offered some weed. Took a puff and within 30 minutes I was passed out on the couch sleeping. That‚Äôs when I realized weed could help me sleep. A decade later and I‚Äôm a heavy smoker smoking away up to 4 or 5 blunts a night just to get high enough to sleep. I had no issues quitting I would quit from time to time for months or even when we had family trips I would not smoke. But I also would suffer from lack of sleep during my break from it. Sleeping pills and melatonin worked sometimes but it wasn‚Äôt enough. I would always go back to smoking weed. But I would immediately feel the negative affects after smoking. The next day I would be so tired. Drinking coffee and energy drinks to get through the day. Weed made me so lazy! I would rather be at home smoking weed than out with my friends enjoying life. A few years ago I got tired of always being high to be able to sleep. Went and got professional help and found the root to my insomnia problems. Now I sleep so much better and have amazing dreams that I did not have while smoking. I wake up rested and no longer need coffee to be productive. Yeah weed can be a fun experience but it also has its dark side. I always wondered why it was illegal for so long and in a lot of states still is. It‚Äôs very addictive and easy and cheap to come by. I don‚Äôt recommend it üòÇ

Name: @dsaikon
Comment:
@@Corgi_fax This is so fax actually, coming from a (former) long time stoner. You're told everywhere that weed isn't dangerous or has close to no side effects, but the truth is, it can have many side effects (mostly mental), and works in different ways for different people. 

Weed is no wonder drug that gets you high without consequences. Besides the fact that most people smoke weed with tobacco, which is clearly very unhealthy in itself and causes respiratory issues, it can cause a variety of mental issues in some people that use it chronically. 
Now, I believe that using it sometimes and not on a regular basis is absolutely fine, but using it frequently or even daily, will alter your brain chemistry a lot. Especially if you're still young and developing. Luckily, most of the side effects can be reversed with a long absence from THC, however most stoners will inevitably build not only a tolerance, but also a dependency on weed. You can become irritable, depressed, prone to insomnia and many more things when quitting, which is why everyone says they can quit easily, but only a handful of people actually do it. 
And by far the worst side-effect is that you lose the ability to dream (or to consciously feel your dreams). This is why when quitting, you can expect to have wild dreams in the first 3 weeks. Dreams are very important for the brain guys, don't sleep on them (pun intended)
This only happens with chronic users though, and we can't fully explain why because we don't know enough about the Endocannabinoid System in our body.

Don't just mindlessly consume anything without being aware of what can happen to your body and your self. The same thing applies to alcohol (even more actually), and any other drug out there. Think for yourself, and don't follow other peoples bad decisions.

Name: @streuthmonkey1
Comment: @@Corgi_fax It isn't a narcotic. Narcotics are drugs consumed for  non-medical purposes. Weed has may medicinal uses and is consumed by many for medical purposes. You are blinded by ignorance and prejudice.

Name: @tricitymorte1
Comment: My situation is quite unique. I've always had issues with insomnia but was only recently diagnosed. I also have depression and anxiety. I didn't smoke weed for years. I've had these issues since I was a child. I also extremely rarely remember my dreams (I usually just say I don't dream, since I wake up and it's basically like I time travelled into the future with no memories of any dreams). I can count on one hand the number of dreams I can remember across my entire 39 years. I do now use weed on a semi-regular basis, but certainly not every day. My tolerance has also been extremely low, since the beginning - low as in 10-15mg. If I go above that by even as little as 5mg, I get very sick. I feel light-headed, extremely weak, my body temperature rises to the point I can feel the heat rolling off of me, and sometimes I end up vomiting, after which I have to lie down. I don't have a choice. I will be unconscious for about an hour. So, I'm very careful about how much I use and how often, and it has been a massive help. I didn't want to be on a bunch of pharmaceutical medications for my mental health issues, and this was the solution to that. Where I live, it's legal recreationally, so I don't need a medical license for it, but my psychologist still offered me one.

Name: @SarahADowney
Comment: PSA: your dreams are an important source of wisdom from your unconscious and subconscious mind, and if you‚Äôre not having them anymore because of weed, it‚Äôs something to seriously consider. I used to use edibles to help fall asleep almost every night for about 2 years. I stopped because I wasn‚Äôt dreaming and felt groggy in the morning. Like a lot of commenters here are also saying, it felt like the backlog of dreams I hadn‚Äôt been having for 2 years just assaulted me. I had like 2-3 weeks of extremely intense, vivid dreams, and then it felt like my system caught up and went back to normal. That said, I have started keeping a dream journal and have noticed some really important advice, themes, and solutions to problems from what has been coming up. I now consider dreams to be an incredibly useful resource, not just random neural firings, and if I‚Äôd keep doing the edibles, I wouldn‚Äôt have noticed. Just something to think about if you‚Äôre looking to level up your life.

Name: @SpectreDelta
Comment: I work in a dispensary and I can tell you that is a very common misconception. Things like "high %" or "indica vs Sativa" are things the most common despite not actually mattering at all. What determines how a strain effects you is determined by the terpenes and cannabinoids present. Some terpenes for example Myrcene are known to have a sleepy, sedative effect and are most common in Indica strains. however some "sativas" have this too and some indicas don't. However there are literally hundreds of different terpenes and it can get confusing so its easier for some people to just say indica or sativa. even though some "sativas" can make you tired and some "indicas" might make you feel more euphoric or energetic

Name: @NobleSainted
Comment:
@MediocreFilms...
Indeed, your point is valid, and I appreciate you raising it. I would also have appreciated more in-depth info, but I also understand how difficult it would be to prove the information as well since true cannabis testing is still in its infancy.

While some may believe that the only distinction between Sativa and Indica is their appearance, I propose that those with such beliefs conduct a small comparative test of there own to demonstrate the significant differences between the two that I believe exists.

With over 120 cannabinoids, these variations yield diverse Physiological / Psychological effects. Though I'm not a medical professional, extensive research or consultation with experts could provide more detailed insights.

Studies isolating these components are underway, confirming the varied effects of each. Therefore, it's accurate to say that there are notable disparities between Sativa and Indica.

Personally, I prefer Hybrids, which in all honesty dominate medicinal plants today.
Even if the strain is denoted as sativa or Indica, this would actually only denote the _dominance_ of said strain type, not the actual purity. Look at it this way...
Many of today's strains have undergone hundreds of years of crossbreeding (some over a thousand). This also occurs naturally (in the wild without genetic manipulation/crossbreeding) as well.

I hope this sheds light on the topic for some.

Name: @nycbearff
Comment:
I'm an old guy, and cannabis in the evening reliably stops my night-time leg cramps, and eases the chronic pain I have from several sources.  None of the medically suggested treatments for those things work nearly as well, and they have worse side effects, some of them much worse.  I do take breaks now and then for a week or two - and then return to the cannabis.  So yes, I'm sure it modifies my sleep.  But, as with most things, it's complicated.  Modern medicine is in it's infancy.  

No one knows why only some people respond to cannabis the way that the majority did in the referenced studies - they were mostly correlation studies, with statistical outcomes, and were mostly done on college students in Western universities. People who didn't have the most common responses were ignored, because studying them further will be very expensive and time consuming.  Eventually, we'll understand our genetics and in vivo cellular processes, and be able to do personalized medicine and personalized recreational highs.  But not in my lifetime - and probably not in yours.  We know very little yet.


So this video talks about some interesting things, and gives a lot of food for thought - but your responses may be different.  The best thing to do would be to experiment, and see what's right for you, with your genetic profile at your age.

Name: @alisonhillary
Comment: This 100% fits with my experience.  I'm a lifelong insomniac - I have memories of my struggle with sleep going back as early as 4-5 years old.  It's well and truly part of my biology.  The first time I tried THC gummies as a sleep aid, I was delighted with the effects.  I have since tried THC & CBD gummies and found them to be even better.  But from the very beginning, I've held them back for emergency use during the worst of my insomnia.  For the regular day to day, I rely on my old standbys of melatonin and behavior therapy.  I had wanted to start slowly out of an abundance of caution (and cost), but quickly found that while it was a tremendous help, it always felt like it wasn't a good idea to use it all the time, so I've kept it to emergencies only, when my insomnia gets really bad.  I feel like this video supports all of my personal conclusions, so I feel even better about continuing to use it exactly as I have been.  (Until and unless additional research comes out to change my perspective on it.)

Name: @learningfromlifewithashley6643
Comment:
I was a chronic user most of my life.  I suffered with severe ptsd and extreme childhood trauma so I always thought I was medicating. 
I WAS over medicating tho. I want to be clear about that.  
I ended up being put on probation and had to quit, that was almost 3 years ago. 

I was terrified.  I was certain I would have worse night terrors and sleep paralysis. I feared I would lose sleep and have more sleep walking, more anxiety and figured my health would decline. 

That wasn‚Äôt the case at all ! 
I became more emotionally stable, I slept better, my anxiety disappeared. I don‚Äôt have any night terrors anymore and no sleep walking. It‚Äôs so crazy ‚Ä¶ I always thought cannabis was keeping me from getting worse. 

Let‚Äôs be very clear tho.. I still believe it was my chronic use.  I still believe it had medicinal use if it isn‚Äôt being abused.  

When I do go back to using it I want to keep my use at a much lower level. 

Thanks for listening/reading my comment :)

Bottom line is THC reduces the amount of time you spend in REM sleep cycles. It also reduces your ability to dream, which is the time you need to actually process day to day emotions.
Smoked pot steady for 25 years, thought I was getting great sleep, never had dreams. Quit 6 months ago and after the initial few days of the worst insomnia I starting to actually get good sleep and feel well rested, my dreams are the most vivd 4k dreams imaginable.
For people going through difficulties with PTSD THC is a great tool, but it is actually ruining your quality of sleep. The trade off is you dont have to deal with crazy dreams.

You're far more likely to want to go and take a nap after smoking some good indica, whereas you're far more likely to want to do something creative after smoking some good sativa.  "Weed" isn't just "Weed".  There's a reason most dispensaries have a large menu of products available, categorized by "indica", "sativa" and "hybrid" strains (and occasionally a "hemp" category if the dispensary carries strains such as "Charlotte's Web"). 

Any study on cannabis that doesn't include any information on the strains of cannabis being used, isn't a study that has actually done their research properly.

Name: @openskies11
Comment: I have severe, chronic insomnia. I actually have been to the emergency room and have permanent neurological damage from sleep deprivation. Cannabis (in the form of cannabutter, 5-10 mg) has a been a lifesaver for me, because it does allow me to sleep if I take it in combination with melatonin and doxylamine, and occasionally with gabapentin and valerian on a bad night, I can actually get a full night's sleep. (I also have to wear a CPAP, it's a whole deal.) The part about dream suppression with THC is 100% true though.  If there are nights when I can get by without cannabis, my dreams are far, far more vivid. When I do use cannabis though, I'm still tired throughout the day and mental alertness isn't so great, a sort of sleep medicine hangover. (This is better than my previous sleep med regimen, which was melatonin + 4x the recommended dosage of doxylamine + valerian + almost an entire fifth of rum, vodka, or whiskey. That too almost killed me.)

I smoked weed for 6-7 years long and around the end of those 7 years I became extremely tired even after sleeping for 8 hours it didnt matter any,more.

The first day going to sleep without smoking was horrible I think I've layed there for 1-2 hours before I finaly fell asleep.
It went the same the next couple of days and for the  first time in many years I could actually remember that I had dreamed , I don't remember them now anymore but I remember that it almost felt like that my brain was on acid.
Now a couple years forward , I'm less tired the heart palpitations has stopped and I feel way better during the day.

Like I read here in the comments THC has its usefullness for people that are actually in need , I'm a believer that weed in some cases is way better than the doctors that prescribe you 10 different pills for 1 condition.
They also say ''weed is a gateway drugs'' and thats also not entirely true , people that  are prone to addiction they might try something else and get hooked on it . People that are not prone to addiction might also try something else but never get hooked on it.

Name: @OriginalMorningStar
Comment:
I have Synaesthesia (born with it, not drug related) and a photographic memory. Both these things mean I dont sleep well and have vivid dreams and visions while awake. Cannabis suppresses this but it has an unintended side effect... I'm a designer among other things, and I use the visions constructively - visualisations of structures, of mathematical constructs, mechanisms etc - which cannabis helps to concentrate on for longer and more fluidly. But when I sleep, that process seems to continue and I often wake with fully formed solutions to things that were on my mind before. I have no recollection of dreaming them, and it used to be a little disturbing, a bit like studying something and not remembering doing so, but having retention of the subject. Unlike normal, when I know how and where I acquired a piece of knowledge... I'm going to go out on a limb here and say its probably the Synaesthesia at the root of this, but its the cannabis enabling it through the REM interaction. I gather that 'normal' dreams are synaesthetic, in that they are full experiences, and I can relate that to my waking experiences compared to my memories. I also know that long-term heavy cannabis use can cause synaesthesia, and that getting really high can temporarily induce it. Everyone I know who smokes, reports that music becomes a more profound experience as a result, but it doesnt change mine a great deal, I've always enjoyed a permanent minds-eye light show in response to sound. It also does not affect my memory, which is unusual I gather, cannabis is known to affect short-term memory. I dont have one, everything goes straight into permanent memory. I should also point out that is a much a curse as a blessing, and cannabis helps me deal with it...
I just thought you might find it interesting to know what the stuff does to an atypical brain as a reference, because most of the effects of cannabis appear to be psychological rather than pathological, and are as a result rather hard to interpret in general. I learned this through extensive psychological testing after misdiagnosis as Aspergers / Autism and was recommended by a psychiatrist to use the stuff rather than prescription drugs with way more deleterious effects.

Name: @BearBlair
Comment:
Im no doctor, but there is a 100% correlation with sleep and THC use, and not in a great way for restful sleep. Literally everyone I know who still smokes, and have been smoking for years (some decades), don't dream very often, can't sleep w/o THC, low overall energy, and say they get terrible sleep (and then blame it on "i slept wrong" instead of their 10+ yrs of using). From someone who has used more than chronic use (high all day for about 3 years straight [never really built a tol]). About 3-6 months off after finally not smoking, I defiantly have noticed a very positive change in my sleep. I can get to sleep quicker, stay asleep more, but I still don't dream really ever. And I mean literally almost never. Although that's probably due to the brain damage I caused from smoking so much. Yeah, I came out of that 3 years with psychosis, and actual brain damage. 9/12 cranial nerves in my brain are shot, and I hallucinate pretty often.. defiantly not for everyone. (Yes it's all diagnosed). I am not telling anyone to not smoke, or to smoke. Do what you please, but please do not smoke until you're brain is fully developed or else you can end up like me. Life long irreversible damage to your brain.

Side note: before I figured out I had brain damage, I did try to go back to THC. Tried this multiples times over the course of a few months, but each time I smoked, my sleep and some other very impactful things suffered DRAMATICALLY for about 2-3 weeks after just using once (1 or 2 puffs, barely really getting my toes wet thb).

Name: @BearBlair
Comment: I am one of the not so common cases of psychosis popping up indefinitely after chronically abusing, but pretty much everything else still stands. Please.. if you're under 25, please stop smoking, it's literally terrible for your brain. There is literally nothing good about it before your brain is done developing.

Name: @danieljmarvin
Comment:
From experience, I find that weed used over a short period of time increase inner experiences but over a long period of time decreases them. Inner experiences include emotions, visualization, the ego etc. Visualization is key (in many people) for  memory and rem sleep. I'm confident in my conclusions. I'm not surprised by any of this. 

10 mg edible once a week after work is the sweet spot. Do it on a day that you relaxing the next day - not going to the gym etc. I do it Friday afternoons. It's the perfect break to where you get to consolidate your experiences throughout the week and you feel no urge to take it afterwards. I don't feel like my life is less when I'm sober. It's like I get a two week vacation every week. I've tried it all. Twice a week is too much if you want a sustainable schedule for the rest of your life. 

Of course, if friends are in town or it's a holiday it's fine to do more but only because you have a health relationship to it. Once you feel a draw to it or sobriety is somehow lacking you've gone (way) to far.

Name: @climbboy4722
Comment: For anyone trying to quit I want to share my own experience. I smoked consistently for 3 years. I stopped because I was hospitalised after having a breakdown due to a combination of factors and using weed as a crutch to escape my feelings of loneliness. The first week of sleep was awful I was waking up between 3 to 6 times a night it was awful. I woke up drenched in sweat but I kept forcing myself back to sleep until I had reached a set time in the morning to get up. Just don‚Äôt leave the bed. After that first week I saw a very quick turnaround of being able to sleep well again. It was then a couple of months later I started having constant sleep interruption again Changing my scenery really helped with this and I have been clean and having good quality sleep since. If you are having trouble sleeping I would recommend changing your bedroom around a bit, reorganise the furniture, change the lighting if you can and make sure your bed is comfortable and change the smell by using a new washing liquid you enjoy. This increases the novelty of falling asleep because changing your sleeping environment creates a weird sensation of being somewhere new and I personally think this works because normally weed makes things seem more novel and entertaining to your brain doing this lets you cut out the chemical component while keeping some of the novelty your brain will still be craving. Hope this helps.

Interesting, I‚Äôve been using cannabis for about 5 months to help with my sleep and I sleep very well on it. I was a heavy cannabis smoker for 34 years, and i quit Cold Turkey about a year ago. The first weeks, months even, the nights have been a nightmare. Sometimes I didn't sleep at all.
