Name: @drakhir
Comment:
Good video - you put things clearly and succinctly. Nice one :)
One point to make about the study of students at 5.40 - it's important to be able to tell the difference between causation and correlation.
Just because people who smoke more weed  have more incidences of insomnia, does not mean it is caused by that. Most people who smoke, roll it with tobacco. So they are more likely to smoke more tobacco as well. Does the study differentiate?
Also as noted earlier, with 50% of people using marijuana to fall asleep, this may be reflected in the figures regarding how much insomnia they continue to have while using. Thus, it could be that the set of insomniacs are far more likely to smoke, thus showing the correlation, rather than the insomnia being caused by the smoking.
That's just two metrics. There are others. Unless the study differentiated between these things, then it cannot show causation; only correlation.
EDIT - okay, you mention this specifically. Nice one ;) However the conclusion you draw is less certain, due to this evidence.
The correlation are the statistics. The causation is the inference. This inference may be unwarranted.

What works for you, though - that's the best data you can use. Glad you're on top of it. My question is always "Who is in control?" If it's not me...
Then I need to do something about it.

Name: @EBiz-tv9jq
Comment:
Marijuana is same hoax as nicotine. 
It is a "cure for everything"
Then is becomes hip
Then it becomes widespread
Then we start noticing that it is not quite right (e.g. psychosis, mental illness catalysator, dependency, damaging memory, analytical powers etc.)
Then we start discovering that it is actually quite harmful (much like nicotine, but in a different way)
Then there are attempts to make it appear healthier by derivatives (such as CBD)
And then the society slowly accepts that it is actually a harmful drug. 
Then a very ong and slow social and legal process begins to oust weed as something a healthy person should ever need. 

I could bet my head, in 25-50 years most countries will already move to ban weed as much as possible. 

Fun fact - almost all weed industry gets their main money from the SAME FUNDS which own cigarette industry. 
The owners just realized cigarettes are falling out of favor, so they lobbied the next available drug - weed.

Name: @Implosion-Gaming
Comment: You're correct, cbd is better because it wont get you high. I think its a good substitute for those who are problematic with high psychoactivity (people with psychopathology). Basically there are pros to using thc like there a pros to getting a beer in after a long week, but not everyday to cope. Then it becomes a question of is the weed helping me improve my mood, or is the weed the only reason im awake. Its truly a tough decision to make when youre deep in doubt and shame about what has occured to us in our lives, but you have to look at the cause and effects. We all do things everyday, but when we look at why we do them, we truly see the source of pain/happiness. Going from high 24/7, to high only when i want to improve my already fun experience, it has been a completely different experience in life, and im happier for making this tough decision.

Different strains are used for specific areas, you have 3, indica, hybrid, and sativa.

 This is more effective and way better than any pill, I've been on horse tranquilizers before, so this is way safer.

 Everyone has depression at some point and is irritable or even moody. Weed isn't addictive or habit forming nor can one overdose. 

 Weed can help with sleep, as it has helped with mine, also with chronic pain with my hips cause I was born breached. 

 It does not have an effect on memory, I've been using it for over 40 years and my memory isn't perfect, it didn't have anything to do with my long term or short term memory. 

 It's also great for those who have an eating disorder as I do. I just don't care for food and it does help me eat. I still only eat once a day but I do eat and don't go to just bones like someone anorexic. 

 With dreams I would say it varies with people, this is another reason I like marijuana. Ever have dreams that are so surreal, you know you were there. I have seen the end of the earth, the rapture, zombies, end of days, it's nice to get a good night sleep once in a while and cannabis helps with them. 

 Withdrawal is in the mind, it's a chemical dependency most of the time, cannabis has no known negative effects, or is known to be addictive. If you have a dependency of pills to say help control diabetes it's not a dependency. 

 Marijuana is actually a safe weed, anything can be considered a drug when it is used incorrectly. You wouldn't try to fly a car would ya? 

 We are even given freely this herb and scripture says we are allowed to use herbs and spices for some kill and some heal. I wonder why the pharmaceutical companies only control or mask problems and not correct or fix them, even scripture tells us to keep away from pharmakiea.

Not military or Iraq, rather emergency services for me so understand somewhat. I have to agree. Chronic pain, stroke, diabetes, PTSD and more have been alleviated so much better since of been on medcan. I was ready to off myself, had the knife in my hand and all, figured the mrs and kids would be better without me and the baggage. I get down moments now and then but not like that any more. I'm certainly not afraid of death but not in a rush to hurry it up any more.

What kicked it off for me was high doses of Targin (endone and other stuff) wasn't working in the slightest. Hell even the hospital hate when I used to go into full muscle back spasm as even when double dosed on morphine it'd still take a dozen odd to pin me to the bed out of sheer pain and frustration. Triple or more dose later and I'd finally get something but they were worried. Since starting I've lopped off the pain tablets down to ibuprofen and panadol (soon to be just ibuprofen). I've knocked 2 tablets and an injection out with the diabetes and in EXTREMELY good check of it, even my toes are still VERY sensitive. I've knocked a few other meds down as well. It's done a bloody good job.

Its good and bad, its literally 50/50 for people if ur like me and have adhd( or have ptsd, add, tinnitus or any other conditions even pain sometimes) it can help u fall asleep well, but there are a couple factors like( tricomb development, cbd, thc, and other canabinoids may very per strain) so if u have a type of weed that will give you a "body stond effect" maybe do to Amber tricombs in combination with the canabinoids (cbd,thc,hhc,ect) also there is a big factor if you smoke it or eat it, also, like this video explains it does effect most people's ram sleep, but thats not a issue for people with ptsd for example since most people with ptsd suffer trauma while in ram sleep, so it could improve quality of sleeping, but it can also help with falling asleep for people having a hard time falling asleep anyway do to adhd and just be thinking to much, or other things that might make it harder to fall asleep compared to "regular" people.

Also i do want to note, i like weed, but you should keep it to a minimum, i do it 24/7, but i would suggest you only do it in the evening before sleeping, not more then 1 a day, also if u suffer from ptsd, and this works for you, but i still want to quit, i would assume u might get wilder dreams, that might be a huge problem.

Also, i want to note that I'm not a expert in the matter nor am i a doctor or anything that would have to do with medical studies, i am just some dude that likes to research a lot, about things i am interested in or passionate about, so don't take this as actual advice‚ù§üòÇ

Name: @ReiverBlue1971
Comment: I smoke to deal with my ADHD but I also have EUPD (Emotionally Unstable Personality Disorder). EUPD means you can experience emotions at an order of magnitude greater than would be considered normal (anger is rage, happiness is euphoria) and you can swing from one to the other nigh on instantly. This is normally caused by childhood trauma triggering the long term exposure of the Amygdala to Cortisol, damaging it. The Amygdala, as said, regulates emotion before being processed by the prefrontal cortex/higher brain functions, but with this damage it goes into overdrive hence the difficulties with emotion (my own issue being extreme anxiety/fear). Weed stops me feeling so much AND slows my brain down enough that ADHD becomes less of a nightmare. Many ADHD suffers have their circadian rhythm disturbed (I get tired at about 3-4am and can't get up much earlier than noon!) but weed allows me to at least get to bed earlier.....I just need to find out how to get up earlier now :P Much that I enjoy it, I'd rather I didn't HAVE to smoke as I can't deny it leaves me "blunt" (pardon the pun) and lazy for the rest of the next day (and it also costs a fortune!).

In personal experience it helps me tremendously with sleep. I had breaks of not using it for long periods of time, few months at the time to few years at the time, and i never got enough sleep or rested in that times.
For me it is not so much about falling to sleep as is the quality of sleep, with marijuana i get completely rested and wake up refreshed for work after 5 or 6 hours of sleep while without it i wake up like somebody beat me up in my sleep every morning, i am sleepy at work and have to drink about half a liter of coffee before noon to even function.
Also, i am and always was very vivid dreamer...without marijuana i dream and remember dreams literally every night multiple times at night, and yes it is cool sometimes because those are experiences and sort "trips" the likes of which i never had even close under the influence of marijuana ( which is supposed to be a bit of psychoactive substance ), which is funny because it turns out my sober brain sleeping is the most potent recreational drug for me. But that impedes my sleep and rest significantly.
I take breaks in usage, due to circumstances most often, but the funny thing is if i would want to take a break on purpose i would have to do it while i am on work leave for holidays or something because it boosts my productivity so much by giving me solid and healthy sleep.

Edit: its interesting that CBD counteracts the caffeine blockage of certain receptors. Maybe i should start using CBD to counteract that effects of caffeine, like few hours after drinking coffee or something...

Name: @bluegender2005
Comment:
I have also started to be a regular consumer when the pandemic started - at first with bigger pauses and then more and more frequently. I only consumed in the evening before going to sleep and also small quantities - quarter till a half of a tobacco mixed joint. It became my late evening ritual because it put me to sleep and gave me the comfortable feeling, that everything is alright.

Not only my dreams have stoped, but the process of waking up in the morning became more and more tedious, requiring a very long time to find the motivation to start with my daily tasks - most of the time i work as a freelancer in the creative sector.

A few weeks after my dreams have stoped something strange started to happen: I started waking up almost at the exact same time every night - 2 till 3 hours after going to sleep and feeling wide awake, needing extra time to sleep again. Luckily I knew that if I went for another hit to fall back asleep will lead to a less than optimal habit.

After the prolonged consume, I used to make 3 to 4 days tolerance breaks and notice that I was always moody, very irritated and sensitive. My memory and concentration dropped significantly. I could function again only when I restarted the daily evening ritual.

The whole take from this should be, that because of the legalising, decriminalisation and widespread societal acceptance, we have became blind to the risk potential of the frequent recreational use of weed. Moderation is the key, and I feel we need more videos like this one, pointing to the adverse effects, rather than the beneficial ones.

Name: @Welgeldiguniekalias
Comment: I've been a very heavy user who smoked high THC weed daily for decades with very few breaks. It became normal for me to stay up way too late, still lie awake for an hour or two every night and then sleep for either less than six hours (because I had to get up for work) or more than ten hours (off days). Recently, I went to smoking only once a week, and found that I was able to sleep for 6-8 hours, but would wake up once in the middle of the night pretty much every night. It definitely shuts up my amygdala and helps to cool me down, but all in all I would say weed has been disruptive to my sleep. I guess I'm quitting regular use now, since it's been over a week and I don't really feel the urge at the moment. And yes, my sleep patterns have become quite normal as a result; no more staying up too late, laying awake, or waking up in the middle of the night.

Name: @loganskiwyse7823
Comment:
Good research here.  Overall, a very accurate representation of where the current science is.

I would say my only complaint is far too many of these studies on both sides are based on anecdotal evidence.  Aka studies where you ask about user's experiences compared to studies done in labs.  While this is in large part due to the still difficult nature of doing real medical studies with marijuana legally it also makes the error factor of the studies, we do have far too high to draw conclusions.

The second part of why this is an issue is a huge number of regular users also have mild to moderate mental health disorders.  Autism, ADHD, and many other disorders have a high undiagnosed but self-medicating population.  Even within the diagnosed communities use is higher than outside those communities.  (Reminder I am talking frequent use compared to occasional recreational use).  This also makes studies based off individual experiences of users subject to error compared to the general population and is not taken into account on many of these studies.

Name: @HonoredMule
Comment:
Not a good start when the first 15 seconds opens with an utterly bullshit statistic.  So I checked.  Technically, it _is false,_ but not so far off as I'd have thought.

Starbucks: 1,429
Taco Bell: 103
Burger King: 359
Wendy's: 418
McDonald's: 1,370

restaurants total: 3,679
cannabis dispensaries: 3,188

Yikes, that's closer than I'd have ever believed.  The more surprising part is how rare Taco Bell is though.  Also...

Tim Hortons: 3,528

Edge out past _that_ number and you'll have a proper sensationalist headline.

Either way, the video opens with an exaggeration (lie), so consider the rest accordingly.  I'm also disappointed that of the 7 sources cited, only _one_ operated on a sufficient sample size but even that one is a very select demographic (university students, so mostly young adults) and the publicly available text truncates every section to uselessness.  The rest average about 60 participants but do at least publish usable abstracts.

I'm predisposed to agree with this video's overall perspective and yet it still looks more to me like an exercise in confirming bias (finding what you sought) than an open-minded analysis.  How much effort went into seeking contradictions and avoiding contextual abuse?  Yes research data is as yet scarce, but it's still up to you _not_ to simplify barely-valid highly-nuanced complexity down to a picture clearly pointing in only one direction.  Enabling people to run around thinking they understand something with which they're barely even acquainted is done easily enough _without_ a science communicator.

Name: @LilChuunosuke
Comment:
I've had insomnia literally for my entire life for as long as I can remember and was worsened due to childhood trauma. I tried everything under the sun before trying weed. Herbal teas, colored lights, exercising a little over an hour before bed, melatonin, sleeping pills, etc. The lifestyle changes made no noticable difference, the melatonin didnt work, and sleeping pills were not really designed for daily use.
Marijuana was literally life changing for me. I fall asleep HOURS faster, I do actually dream more, and I wake up less often in the middle of the night. I recently converted from gummies with 1mg of THC to pure CBD & while I have noticer it is ever-so slightly less effective, I still have a higher quality of life thanks to this drug.
I highly recommend keeping your tolerance levels low, regardless of whether you're using CBD, THC, or both. I have never consumed more than 20mg of CBD or 5mg of THC for sleep and I am currently trying to lower my THC tolerance back down to 10mg doses. Part of the reason for these side effects are probably due to large dosages. I will praise the benefits of marijuana all day every day, but always consume in moderation and take tolerance breaks when you stop feeling the benefits instead of increasing your dosage.

Name: @youwokeuplate
Comment:
I have been an insomniac as long as I can consciously remember. I began relying on weed to sleep and it seemed like a life saver. I used nightly probably 3 years, until I saw a video about how weed reduces ur ability to dream (which I experienced) which inhibits your subconscious ability to process emotions. This alarmed me, and I also felt like weed just wasn‚Äôt putting me out like it used to, and I found myself staying awake and needing more doses.

So, I switched to only CBD capsules and then in a matter of time, ended up replacing both with transcendental meditation.. which I didn‚Äôt anticipate using as a sleep aide. 

I am an artist w an overactive mind and wanted to try TM morning and night simply to help calm my mind and help my creative intuition/process. And from day one, it ended up putting me to sleep that night, maybe even quicker than THC ever did.

I learned meditation with a therapist for a year before this then but never found a meditation I could rely on to work to clear my anxious mind this quickly. TM does it for me. I am amazed I have slept every night without weed, without worrying, without hours of spiraling thoughts. I wake up feeling so proud of myself.

Note I also incorporated less screen time overall pretty much eliminating all social media (which greatly reduced my overactive mind) and replaced that habit with journaling. Stream of conscious journal before my nightly TM is hugely beneficial. I am so grateful to have found a technique I can rely on that isn‚Äôt substance. I know a lot of our life circumstance that cause stress is out of control. But u need to reduce stress where u can help it and overconsumption of media is a big stressor a lot of us would rather overlook bc we like the facade of connection and the mind numbing it brings. You are better without it, trust me.

Name: @jlb9210

I use weed to sleep and now live a much better and rested life than when I didn't use it and was chronically sleep-deprived (life-long insomniac).  Weed is amazing for my sleep and I will never stop using it for that purpose.

Name: @robert5507
Comment: This video explains my personal experience with marijuana to the tee. I smoked almost daily from age 18 to age 28, with a huge increase in tolerance/dosage of weed coming in the later years. From the time I was 18 to 28, I would take a break for one or two days each month, and boy were those some of the wildest/vivid dreams I ever had. At age 28 I decided to quit cold turkey, and boy was that a nightmare. For about 3 months, I probably only slept 2-3 days. There were multiple days in those 3 months where I did not get sleep AT ALL; I'm talking that deep, REM sleep, I got none as I felt awake the whole night;  I had to call in sick for 2 weeks at work and I felt EXTREMELY depressed. Withdrawal symptoms were a surprise to me since I could take 1 or 2 days off in my younger days without any ill effects. I wish I knew about withdrawal symtomps beforehand. Currently, I began smoking again but maybe once a week and I am much better now. I agree people need to cycle on and off of it or not use it daily.

Name: @JBreaz
Comment:
Don't know if this will be seen but I've been using for years. Like a decade plus. Here are the things I noticed compared to my friends who have been using for just the same amount of time.

The sleep thing seems to be on track. Sorry to say. I have had a good ritual of smoking before bed and I do notice that in the long run  more often than not I'm staying up with my high. I usually don't get tired from it. 

My friends on the other hand are almost guaranteed to fall asleep within 20 mins. 

I've noticed that my sleep has been more or less the same with or without weed.
In 2020 on the onset of the pandemic I stopped smoking entirely. I didn't wanna chance smoking with a lung based disease going around. (Yes I know 10 years of smoke inhalation has definitely done damage, chill).

During the time that I stopped and we were in lockdown I generally became much healthier. I never really missed smoking, never really missed being high. Worked out a bunch and got great sleep. I was unprovoked. Started having dreams again. It was fine but I didn't feel any different. Honestly.

I just started back up again and I have to say it's kind of "eh". Like, I was never one to use it as an escape. I always valued it for the introspection it offered me and the "zeroed in" vibe i got when making music or any art. To me it was a tool.

Here's the interesting part: 

The older I got the more I saw a shift from it being a useful tool to becoming something that kind of was a detriment. It became a source of anxiety. Especially during my Masters. I passed out many times and had doom-level panic attacks when high. That incredible pull of doom down to the ground. Not good. Lol. 

One of my friends, who definitely leans on it as a crutch, has had the opposite experience. He seemingly counts on it to alleviate his anxiety and get to sleep. Whereas when we were younger he had panic attacks more often.

I think this has a lot to do with age and general stress, which I think is something that should be researched too.

Now I'm lucky if I smoke once a week if that. Tbh I went so long without it I kinda don't care for it anymore.

Hope this anecdotal evidence was interesting.

Name: @LluviaGloom
Comment: I work in the Mj industry and am surrounded by a culture that romanticizes getting a higher tolerance e.g. (heady glass scene, gram dabs, constantly getting high) but because tasting hash rosin is basically our job and while I do love what I do I've noticed that getting high is no longer enjoyable because it can feel like I'm underwater and my feelings of anxiety and paranoia are dramatically increased with symptoms of my heart racing, auditory hallucinations, and strong headaches. I've been smoking nonstop for 7 years and within the last 2 years I've cut down on smoking/ vaping/ eating edibles because of this. it's so strange how as you age your high also changes. sometimes I force myself to smoke because of how much I love the taste and smell of these new genetics but usually end up giving myself a full-on panic attack. This video was spot on in terms of what happens when you completely stop using marijuana. Thanks for this video!

Name: @J_McPhearsom

As someone with Narcolepsy, and thus have no brain regulation of sleep, I‚Äôve found weed to be the ONLY consistent way to induce ‚Äòwinding down‚Äô, ‚Äòrest & digest‚Äô, and finally sleep. There are no other sleep aids I can recommend to take for weeks or longer, without major side effects. 
And with Narcolepsy, I have a problem falling asleep during day, and going directly into REM sleep in less than 1 minute (<20 minutes is cutoff for narcolepsy) in MSLT. So I can actually use low dose pot, to hold off Narcoleptic attacks for 2 hours during day, till I‚Äôm safe to fall asleep. (Since, as mentioned, it reduces one‚Äôs ability to fall into REM sleep, especially on the ‚Äúcome-up‚Äù)

Name: @norXmal
Comment:
Currently on my 1 month and second week break from Cannabis, the first 2 weeks were the worst with waking up drenched in sweat, difficulty to fall asleep and waking up almost as tired as I did before going to sleep and constant bombardment of thoughts when trying to sleep, while anxiety was starting kick back in.
After week 3-4, everything started to progress somewhat rapidly, I started to have a lot of vivid but unusual dreams, which was quite refreshing from not having any before I stopped.
I've started to gain more energy than I did before I stopped, but I will admit I sometimes crave it, more so when my back pain(scoliosis) starts acting up or under stressful situations.
If there is one thing for certain, when consuming THC, it will be in moderation and much stricter at that, only used when necessary, maintaining low tolerance.

Name: @oliverm3589
Comment: I just had my first smoke in over a month yesterday. I try to take at least a months break a couple times a year. When I'm smoking I usually find myself smoking multiple times a day every day until I run out. For me the main negative effects I get when not smoking are heavy night sweats. If I'm not smoking I have to wear something that covers my legs otherwise I'll wake up multiple times a night and won't be able to get back to sleep because my legs just feel disgusting from all the sweat. The dreams usually kick in after 3ish weeks and man do they get wild. Very vivid and either I get completely absorbed in them to the point they feel real even after I wake up, or completely lucid where I know 100% I'm dreaming and can control them. Weirdly I find the increased boredom when not smoking becomes a benefit in that I become more motivated to do basic self-care/maintenance, because I get bored and can't procrastinate by just getting high.

Name: @norXmal

@@oliverm3589 That's a great point, the procrastination issues when you stop as that's what it usually becomes, if not that it's another substance to fill the gap.

Name: @myfairjew
Comment: I've been using cannabis everyday for the past 15 years (my entire adult life), so take what I say with a grain of salt because I have very little idea of what it is like to abstain for an extended period of time. I don't have any issues with insomnia, and I am a natural heavy sleeper (based on what I remember from childhood/adolescence). In terms of sleep, what I experience is almost like a temporary hangover. It takes me almost an hour to get out of bed in the morning (hittin' that snooze over and over again baby), which is attributable to the fact that I am likely being woken up in the middle of a sleep cycle. Keep in mind that this is a daily routine. I'm always up at this time of the day, but its always hard for me to get out of bed. But, once I'm up, I feel well rested throughout the day. I think the way weed affects sleep will vary quite a bit from person to person, and even the same change in the sleep cycle will affect people differently. I've also been known to sleep through my alarm if I go to bed too late (only if I'm to be up before my normal time), which is not good for employment longevity.

Name: @kkaixer
Comment:
Well, where i use it it is illegal.
I have sum sleeping issues since im 4. And no, i dont have any traumas from that age. It just started at that age. So, i am having trouble falling asleep, and if i by any chance fall asleep, i usually cant go to deep sleep and if i feel uncomfortable during my sleep, i automatically wake up, change position and try to sleep again which takes another hour or so. This influenced my learning ability, daily life quality and many other things inclusive memory.

Since i started to use weed at least the first two years, i was able to sleep good. But with time i started to  develop the anxiety that i wont be able to sleep without weed, which as you said caused me to use higher doses with time. 
Now, good sides back then was good sleep, a very active mind which  helped me with work and develop new ideas but it made me extremely weak in memory. Well, bcz of sleeping issues my memory was already weak but while giving a broader view on my thoughts weed also took the sharpness away.

The other side effect is that, it really makes you lazy and careless. Which is not so preferable. 

Another problem is that, it opens your system to alergies. Yesh, using too much weed causes cotton mouth but if your eyelids feel scratchy all the time, it means you have too much thc in your body, which you should get rid off asap. 
The mucosal secretion is restricted because weed affects the processing of water in the body. Nasal dryness, means more germ into your body more allergens etc.


But i also have exprienced that if you can stop using weed for at least two days, you stop desiring it. Difficult two days...

But i wanted to see how far i can go so i stopped vaping it for at least 4 months. 

This helped me to get rid off even those weird mood swings. And i felt really clear. And the sharpness came back.

Btw i definetly recommend to take vitamin B, which helps you in so many ways, espcially in this case. 

After that i have found the best ratio for me of daily use, which is 0.25 grams. 

I vape it around 20:00 after dinner(less to none munchies). I experience a very quality high. I dont get the side effects like dryness in my nose and so on.

And when its effects wears off, i feel a sweet sleepy mood.

Now there are some No-Go's.
1. Don't vape it in the morning or during the day. It will have bad influence.
2. Experience your high till the end and never go to sleep while you are high.
3. Do not combine it with any other drugs, inclusive coffee.
4. Any sativa higher than 70% can cause panic, confusion, paranoia.
5. Any indica higher than 70% can cause depression, isolation, melancholia

Name: @itsanapesworld
Comment: So: Ive been a daily user for aprox 14 years, Ive fallen into a depression in the last few years and this week finally decided to quit daily usage, especially since no matter how much i smoke, i dont feel any effect anymore, it works on me kinda like an antidepressant, stabilizing my mood, but not allowing for "highs" in my mood, and still having "downs". In the last few nights since quitting (notice im still smoking CBD to alleviate the withdrawal symptoms) I indeed have more, as well as much more vivid dreams, but Ive also noticed, that my sleep paralysis (that I had almost every night when I was a teenager before consuming thc) is back - yesterday Ive waited for about 3 hours to fall asleep because of that, and now i wonder if thc could have a positive effect on sleep paralysis in particular. Is there any research about this? Anyways Cannabis is still a drug even if its in my view one of the less harmful ones. Dont take regular use to lightly since the psyche gets very dependant on it. Also ive noticed that I'm much more talkative since quitting and I cried the first time in years (not a depressive crying but tears of joy), I even feel my body much more and feel more connected to people and my surroundings. So do not ever take it to "hide" who you truly are because that was the reason Ive fallen into deep addiction from it! Be careful and accept yourself for what you are - no point in trying to hide it by dampening yourself to a "zombie" like state! If its used recreationally and with care (not regularly) Ive had a lot of friends who it really helped getting over some of their anxieties, but it can only be part of a solution, the rest is up to you! Love yourself, so you can bring love into our hate filled world!

Name: @SuperHonkyPodcast
Comment:
I've been on a multiple year bender of smoking weed every single day and recently decided to quit for financial reasons.
Because of this, my sleep this last week has been absolutely terrible!  I've been averaging only 2 hours of sleep a night
no matter HOW TIRED I feel when I lay down in bed.   Not only that.. I roll around in bed for a good hour after I wake up
just HOPING that I'll fall back asleep.. but I never do.  This leads me to hopping out of bed in an absolutely terrible mood!
The good news is.  I've had the same issue in the half dozen other times I've stopped smoking weed throughout the years
and it typically gets resolved within 10-14 days of quitting.  Here I sit.. day #6 of not smoking weed, and I feel like a HOT
mess!  I've been raging, depressed, feeling down and out, no energy, and have even had plenty of suicidal thoughts in just
this last week since walking away from marijuana.  It's ironic that this video pops up in my feed as I'm smack dab in the
middle of the insomnia faze.  The thing that sucks even more is, typically I used to only smoke flower.  And flower is not
as potent as THC cartridges that we smoke with vape pens.  So typically about in about a week my sleep would improve
significantly.  However.. these last two years I've stepped completely away from flower and have only been vaping the
THC cartridges you can buy.  So this time around it feels even HARDER on me.  It used to be that if I stopped smoking
flower, the only thing that would really SUCK is the lack of sleep for about a week.  This time around however, not only
am I suffering from insomnia, but I've been dealing with higher anxiety than normal, crazy amounts of rage, and even
thoughts of suicide.  Every morning that I'm forced to get out of bed I can't help but think about the pistol that's under
my bed and even went as far as telling my Wife to hide the pistol from me out of sight out of mind.  I don't exactly think
I'd ever be the type to commit suicide, but even the thoughts of that being an option is absolutely terrifying.  

Wish me luck!

Name: @jb34ch1
Comment: Similar story for me after smoking daily for about 20 years. I decided to quit one day when I realized that I was smoking all of my money away. I had also just hooked up with a cute girl who didn't smoke, so it seemed like the perfect opportunity to start a new chapter of my life. The first month was pretty rough with body temperature irregularity and headaches. I was confused about this at first, but then I realized that it was just withdrawal symptoms. My body chemistry eventually normalized, I wasn't overheating at night and dopamine began to be produced naturally. The dreams though, they were intense. The most vivid and wild dreams I've ever had. They were so intense that they would wake me up and I wouldn't be able to get back to sleep for fear of returning to the circus or simply because my heart was racing. It's been a couple years since I quit and the dreams are still vivid but nowhere near as intense. Sometimes, my dreams are odd and nonsensical, other times they can be mundane, but they're always full of details. I've started taking melatonin before bed which helps with falling asleep, but more importantly, it helps to get back to sleep if my dreams inevitably wake me up.

Name: @YerpDerp17
Comment: I am now in my mid 30's and as someone who wasn't a stranger to drugs in my early 20's, I have realized a lot.  I currently only use Marijuana.  I don't drink or consume nicotine.  But I get WAY more benefits from Marijuana by simply microdosing.  I take a hit or two in the evening, and its enough to calm my brain down, but I am not fried.  It keeps my tolerance in check, I spend way less money and I just overall feel better.  I will always believe Marijuana has its benefits, but its all dependent on the user and how they use it.  I still have my nights where I may have some friends over, or my wife and I are kiddless for the night, so we will do a little more, just to unwind and have fun.  But it is not something we do often.  And though we still use it daily, we used to use more in a day than we do in 2 weeks now. lol Weed is so strong now, that 1 or 2 hits does more than enough.  I feel like more than that is overkill, especially if used that way daily. But I think its the same for most substances.  Most of the benefits exist in the lower doses, and you start to see the negatives of use when you consume larger amounts.  Especially frequently. But I swear by microdoses thc.

As a daily smoker, if I had a solid 8 hours to sleep, I'd get a solid 8 hours of sleep. The problem with working 2 jobs to support children that also want time and attention in the few hours that I have to actually sleep.
Now that the capitalist driven pre-apocalypse dystopian nightmare that is life in the United States of America is out of the way, there are two distinct and different types of Marijuana: sativia and indica. Sativia is a stimulate, so taking it for insomnia is counterproductive unless you have a hyperactivity issue. Indica, on the other hand, will help. Talk to your herboligist and make sure you're getting the right kind for the right mind.

Name: @userdudeguy
Comment: I smoked since 2010, quit using September 1, 2023, was a daily bong/ gravity lung user.  The dreams right now are crazy!! End of the world scenarios of hometown, anything I watch such on youtube videos before bedtime, good and evil dreams (even though I am not religious') at first it was hard, couldn't eat, especially breakfast in the mornings would feel nauseous just trying to eat some eggs or whatever else,  sleep was kind of hard at first since I felt I had more energy and felt like I needed a hoot.  But eventually after about 2-3 weeks, eating started to come easier, the food started to taste good again,  I am still literally coughing up lots of black phlegm even though its been 6 weeks since my last smoke.  But overall, I feel I have better sleeps, my mood swings from not smoking went away, I feel I have more energy during the day and have the need to get "things done" as opposed to when I just smoked up, worked and then coming home needing a "hoot" from the stress and then play games all evening, while somewhat still being a parent, my place is now cleaner as I wouldn't clean up as much and was generally lazy while high most of the time.  I guess all good things come to an end, I always thought while I was high I need to quit. To actually do it is up to you and no one else, once you get over that little withdrawal phase, life gets good again and you can enjoy it without them red eyes at family gatherings.

I'm an iraq war veteran. I self medicated with cannabis heavily when I got back. I've probably spent at least 5 years as a daily smoker. Everyone in my family tells me how happy they are that I don't use it anymore. Everytime I try using it again I sink to a new low. For many people like me, it may seem like it alleviates problems in the short term, in the long term it problems much worse. That doesn't mean it won't work for anyone. And it should be studied rather than simply prohibited, as prohibition just makes people untrustworthy of the system and more likely to abuse it. I was angry about the Iraq war and lost trust for my government and that drove me to use cannabis and other prohibited substances.

And while alcahol isn't a good drug to use for recration, people in the US are much more likely to use it in moderation compared to cannabis users.

Name: @matsumoribear
Comment: My assessment: While the info presented is useful & interesting, it really comes down to chemistry - which means (1) composition; (2) dosage; & (3) biochemistry of the subject. So you've got variability in human physiology (which is complicated) being affected by diverse compounds in cannabis (the proportions of cannabinoids, terpenes, etc.) & how the endo-cannabinoid system responds, & you've got the variability of dosage. FDA approved pharmaceuticals could be said to have the same or similar issues but for the variability within the cannabis itself. Different "strains", different growing conditions, homogenization of samples to even it all out. It's herbal science at this stage.

Name: @HumanOddity69
Comment: It really comes down to if the time is right to start dreaming again. There are negative effects to not dreaming but the tradeoff for someone like me is that my unmedicated dreamscape can be more powerful and real than a standard dose of a psychedelic and when a dream like that becomes a nightmare it is one of the worst mental experiences that I can describe so shutting it off is sometimes a survival tactic. That said, dreams have a powerful ability to introduce change to your life, cause you to look at things that you may not be aware of and solve problems. In other words, if you are stuck in life then you need them but if you are not then you kind of don't. I would strongly recommend at least a 1 month break every year for any smoker because you can get lost in being stuck, fail to recognize that a dream can unstick you and then look to cannabis to solve a problem that it causes. It's good to take a step back and make for sure that you are never doing this because it is a trap.

Name: @juanpabloprieto4929
Comment:
This seems pretty incomplete as an evaluation of THC on sleep, though. One of the most important factors is to see whether this REM sleep impact depends on dose and timing of THC, we know coffee to negatively affect sleep if consumed late and within not enough half lifes; saying drinking coffee overall is bad for sleep is poor science, as much as saying THC mere consumption would impact sleep without understanding the concentration curves and sleep timing. 

However, simply the systemic concentration of THC or its metabolites could long term be what has an impact. The data is particularly difficult to get a correlation from as from those students we can correlate THC consumption to insomnia, but we can not see if they used it in an appropiate time (theoretical) time window.

Name: @fatuousinnovatorofsadness4640
Comment:
It's not a trade off of problems!  It's actually a problem you ALREADY had, but never noticed.  

Basically humans have like a certain bandwidth of expression.  You know, if everything was firing off at once, it'd be hectic.  So our brain can only keep track of or hand out energy/thought space to a certain amount of things.  And if you're REALLY bogged down by something, then that leads to other lesser things getting pretty much shut off.  A good physical example of this is that you won't even notice your anger creep in when you're hungry, because the hunger is all you can feel.  

So for anxiety, you were being assaulted by that anxiety and it ended up making you do a thousand little inefficient "what if" thought processes, which led you to be concerned and swept up.  Your life was lived in the battleground between your anxiety and the world around you.  But... then you got some help with weed.  It absolved your anxiety, maybe because you had a realization after smoking that helped you out, or maybe because it taught you how to calm your nervous system down.  

Your anxiety was ultimately reduced because, well, it's not the anxious thoughts which cause the anxiety.  It's the system being anxious that causes the thoughts - and weed relaxes anxious systems usually.  

Now, you face a problem that weed can't fix.  Negative emotions in relation to society.  This was a part of you just like your anxiety was, it has been for probably just as long.  But something in your past hit you in a way that made a little indent in your brain.  And now those negative emotions come from that.  But they only come from that because it's activated within your brain.  Before, the anxiety took it all up.  This new thing is just like the anger.  Your anxiety(hunger) took up all the space, and you never noticed that bad relationships(anger) with the world were formed.  

You can use the weed to help you on your search, sometimes it can open you up to things you wouldn't know without it, or you can go sober and start truly exploring, diving in, and learning the language of YOU, learning the landscape of you, learning your faults and your bumps and your scary dark corners and the parts of you that you hadn't even known were so beautiful until you actually looked at yourself.  

Straight up, just get to work becoming a more beautiful person.  Whether or not weed is involved, it's truly the best journey a human can go on.

Name: @1stHalf

I've help her keep a more stable mentality though and she still smokes weed. She falls asleep a lot easier now too. I think people with anxiety or depression should not be smoking weed unless you can learn to control your response to your thoughts.

Name: @fatuousinnovatorofsadness4640
Comment:
@@1stHalf I used weed myself because it was the only thing that would help me associate.  After that, though, I went a long time without.  I was totally "fine" - no anxiety, no issues at all really - but still not where I wanted to be, blocked in some way from getting there at all.  I would smoke, though, and the anxiety (or whatever was hurting me) would come up, and I would be able to examine it and deal with it on my terms.  I would get a bad thought and instead of saying "the weed did this" I would realize, no, my own brain made this happen, the weed just stirred it up for me to see.  

And with that I specifically smoked to make myself uncomfortable, and to use that state to understand what was wrong within myself that made me react that way to weed.  I ended up fixing almost all of my really hard to pin down problems because I was basically constantly exposing myself to their various external expressions and literally pinpointing exactly where they were coming from while sober, just a constant dance of finding out what's wrong and fixing it.  Idk, worked like magic for me.

Basically I can either take a ton of phama pills or smoke weed for my sleep. It gets rid of my Adult Night Terrors and gives me sleep paralysis. Also solve my narcolepsy too. Seems like weed is bad for normal humans, while the rest of us of who brain problems greatly benefit from it. Too bad the study doesn't cover terpenes which is really the secret sauce. Might below the scientific community way when papers come out showing how CBD and THC isn't really the major benefit of Marijuana, but instead terpenes :)

It's not that you're not having dreams (you can't not have dreams) but you're just not able to remember them. 

It suppresses (or shortens) REM which is where dreams occur. By doing this it not only makes dreams shorty but also decreases your ability to remember them also known as dream recall. 

There are other things in life that can also cause a major lack of dream recall like stress, lack of sleep and aging

Name: @wj2036
Comment: @@YaNansCrustyToe there's several videos you can watch for more information. The jist is that if you smoke less quantity, and only once a day, your tolerance will stay low. Thanks.

Name: @HonoredMule
Comment:
@@YaNansCrustyToe  I'd wager that's a good long term frequency limit but would suggest taking a full month pot free before resuming, if for no other reason than to have (theoretically) an actual baseline for comparison.  But if you're looking for an actually medically informed opinion, I doubt _anyone_ here is remotely qualified to provide one.  It certainly isn't me, and I'm pretty sure it's not the video author either.

There's a good chance it's no one since we simply don't have adequate research on long-term cannabis physiological effects.  We can identify that 30 days seems to be about enough to completely remove non-permanent THC _tolerance,_ but we know next to nothing as far as I can tell about how that correlates to any other physiological effects.  But I'd wager (in my very non-expert opinion) that you haven't got a physiological baseline if you haven't even achieved a tolerance reset.

Comment:
For example: I actively try to remember my dreams. I work on dream recall practices like keeping a dream jorunal and weed is a huge hindrance to my practice. If I'm not keeping up on the journaling while smoking it slips. But if I quit and still don't journal or take less than avergae my dreams will become very vivid. 

Plus it possibly has had an effect on your dream recall and here's how uou can tell:
Are your dreams vivid?
Do they feel like real life?
Do they feel more real than real life? 
Do you have your senses?
Do your dreams tell great stories?

If your answer is no to two or more then this is likely effecting your dream recall but not in any way that's directly noticeable
